data.text: Contents
The Delivery of Treatment and Clinical Trials at the Helen Rollason Research Centre 7
Non Trust Staff Use of Patient Records for Research .................................................. 8
Introduction
The purpose is to define the research services provided by Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust in the Research Centre at the Broomfield site.
The principal benefit of the service to the patient is that they are accessing novel agents well in advance of their availability in routine practice.
By offering treatment in the context of a clinical trial, not only is the service offering novel agents but the cost saving to the NHS is considerable.
The other benefit of participating in clinical trials is that the understanding of treatment in different diseases can be clearly understood and evidenced based practice can lead to best practice.
Scope
The purpose of this guidance is to:

To provide a high quality patient centred Research Service to the population of Mid and South Essex (approximately1.3 million) serving outpatient activity within clinical trials. The Service also receives a number of referrals from within the whole of Essex and Eastern region for access to clinical trials which may not be offered elsewhere in the network or at other sites within MSE.

To provide access to Consultant Oncologists, Haematologists, Physicians, Rheumatologists, Cardiologists and all other suitably qualified and experienced Clinicians involved in recruitment to clinical trials, via the day case setting.
To allow access to clinical trials for patients within the Mid and South Essex area and prevents the need for extensive travel to other clinical trial centres in London.

To provide high quality outpatient intravenous, chemotherapy, oral and other modality therapy services (including supportive therapy such as blood transfusions, IV antibiotics and bisphosphonates for patients on clinical trials).
The team provide an Out of Hours service for patients undergoing all chemotherapy for cancer and other specialities in line with current guidelines.
To provide administration and clerical support for medical and nursing teams. The Research Centre will run from 08.00 – 18.00 Monday to Friday, excluding Bank Holidays.
To provide clinical research laboratory support and process laboratory research samples.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committees Duties are:
Research and Development Committee will approve any MSE sponsored clinical trials (CTIMP) to be delivered at the RC
Individuals Duties are:
Medical / Clinical Oncology Leads are responsible for managing the medical workforce.
Lead Research Nurse is responsible for managing the research nursing workforce.
Principal Investigator is the person accountable, who is responsible for the conduct of the clinical trial within the Trust.
Research Nurses are responsible for the delivery of the services within the R&D service and Research Centre.
Clinical Trial Pharmacist – responsible for the management of Clinical Trial Investigational Medicinal Products (CTIMPS) within the Trust including HRRC.
MLA is responsible for processing any research laboratory samples.
The delivery of treatment and clinical trials at the Research Centre
This policy covers the delivery of treatment and clinical trials at the Research Centre (RC).
Therapy is divided into sessions appropriate to a specific protocol throughout the day. This will be adapted to the individual patient as necessary to deliver the required regimen.

Six treatment stations will be available to deliver therapy at any one time. The RC can deliver outpatient chemotherapy/IV therapy and is able to deliver SACT /support therapies when taking part in a clinical trial.

Haematology services: Clinical Trials patients requiring interventions and blood transfusions with adherence to MEHT Blood Transfusion Policy or Equivalent. This service is delivered by staff who have achieved specific blood transfusion competency.
Rheumatology Service: Clinical Trials using IV and oral therapy for rheumatology patients.
Cardiology Service: Clinical Trials, interventional and observational, for patients accessing the cardiology services.
Diabetes Service: Supporting Clinical trial activity for diabetes patients.
There will be a degree of cross cover between the Chemotherapy Day Unit and the Research centre in the event of sickness or in the event of capacity issues.
Inclusion criteria:
Patients that have consented for a clinical trial and require IV, chemotherapy, oral or other modality therapy in accordance with existing MSE SACT and operational policies;
Ongoing assessment for adverse events for patients on a clinical trial;
Admission avoidance for clinical trial patients with toxicities identified through the  hour pager or telephone triage within working hours;

Patients care will be directed to the Research Centre once they have completed the appropriate informed consent for inclusion into a Clinical trial, or in the pre- screening phase to ensure timely recruitment in line with the clinical trial protocol. These patients are identified through direct referral from a clinician, nurse specialist or during the MDT meetings in the case of cancer patients.
Exclusion
Any patient not on a clinical trial except in 5.8 and 5.12;
Any trial that takes longer than the hours available at the centre;
Any patient below the age of 18 and above the age of 85 years as per most generic research trial protocols inclusion/ exclusion criteria.
Patient flow through the Research Centre:
The patient consents to being treated/ observed in a clinical trial and to having their treatment in the Research Centre;
If a patient has been identified at the other two sites then the research nurse at that site needs to contact the Lead Research nurse to arrange transfer.
PI or research nurse make a referral to the research centre to ensure the standard care costs are recuperated;

The referring research nurse remains the key contact for the patient however the patient will be allocated a treatment nurse for the duration of their treatment while participating in a study at the research centre. The research centre staff confirm referral is in line with the Research Centre Policy;
Care plan and responsibilities agreed (duties of the research nurse and research administration staff are established);
Care received in the RC for the duration of the clinical trial treatment phase
Patient is discharged from the RC to the care of the PI and research team back into the outpatients setting and/or to the referring site ;
Follow-up details as per flow chart (refer to appendix 2).

In the case of urgent chemotherapy cases or a problem with capacity in the Chemotherapy Day unit, the Research centre can be utilised for standard of care chemotherapy treatments. This must be in agreement with the Chemotherapy Lead Clinician, Chemotherapy Nurse Consultant and Lead Research Nurse.

In the event of an emergency situation (for example a patient being unwell while at the research centre), the PI will arrange transfer of the patient to the appropriate department in the Trust and will liaise directly with the on call team to arrange admission.
Infection prevention
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Infection Prevention Policies, and all Infection Prevention Audits completed in designated time frame.
Contingency
In the event of a major incident the service would refer to the Trust Major Incident policy and the Business Continuity Policy.
In the event of the aseptic unit not being available chemotherapy production would be outsourced to an appropriate provider if appropriate for an IMP e.g. private provider, neighbouring NHS Trust.
In the event of the computer system not being available for results the relevant department would be contacted by phone.
In the event of the Trust telephone system being unavailable Trust policy would be followed.
In the event of the Research Centre being unavailable, appropriate accommodation would be utilised within the Trust i.e. chemotherapy unit, IV therapies, OPD facilities.

In the event of a shortage of specialist staff able to administer chemotherapy, staff may be allocated from within the cancer/IV therapy service if competent with the appropriate skills and also approach bank and agencies for staff if appropriate.
In the event of IT failure, paper documentation is completed and uploaded when IT systems are re-established.
Training requirements
All staff adheres to the Trust's mandatory training programme and Training Needs analysis.
In house training for junior medical staff provided by consultant and associate specialist.

Medical and nursing staff will also attend conferences and courses relevant to their role as required. This will include management of oncological emergencies; management of chemotherapy related toxicities; palliative care; symptom control and the safe prescribing and administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy.
Nursing staff undergo training relevant to their area and role. This will include:
Care and administration of the patient undergoing chemotherapy, IV therapy and Other modalities in the context of a clinical trial;
Core skills;
End of life care and symptom control;
Advanced Care Planning;
Mental Capacity Act;
Care of the cancer patient;
Training in the administration of clinical trials;
Other relevant course appropriate to their role and place of work;
Chemotherapy Competencies approved by Nurse Consultant for chemotherapy;.

Chemotherapy will only be able to be administered by chemotherapy competent nurses, who have also passed an annual written exam, and that have been signed off as competent by an assigned assessor and of completed a SACT competency passport;
Medical equipment competencies;
Participation in mandatory infection control audits.
Blood Transfusion training yearly update.
All research staff adheres to the Helsinki Agreement and receive Good Clinical Practice Training, renewed every two to three years.
For the Research Nurse coordinating a specific clinical trial to undertake specialist trial specific training under instruction from the trial sponsor.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Research and Development Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local research guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Research and Development Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
